title: Joseph Mendelssohn
text:
Joseph Mendelssohn (11 August 1770 – 24 November 1848) was a <a href="German%20Jews">German Jewish</a> banker.
He was the oldest son of the influential philosopher <a href="Moses%20Mendelssohn">Moses Mendelssohn</a>. In 1795, he founded his own banking house. In 1804, his younger brother, <a href="Abraham%20Mendelssohn%20Bartholdy">Abraham Mendelssohn Bartholdy</a>, the father of the composers <a href="Fanny%20Mendelssohn">Fanny</a> and <a href="Felix%20Mendelssohn">Felix Mendelssohn</a>, joined the company. The bank <a href="Mendelssohn%20%26amp%3B%20Co.">Mendelssohn & Co.</a> continued under the control of the <a href="Mendelssohn%20family">Mendelssohn family</a> and would rise to prominence during the 19th century, becoming one of the most important and influential German banks during the early 20th century.
Descendants.
Joseph's descendants include the <a href="neurologist">neurologist</a> <a href="Alexander%20Carl%20Otto%20Westphal">Alexander Carl Otto Westphal</a> (1863–1941) and the <a href="musician">musician</a> <a href="Ben%20Parry%20%28musician%29">Ben Parry (musician)</a> (b.1965).
